conversation.text: Did you catch the perch yourself?
evidence: If you caught the perch yourself, you'll want to fillet your perch first

conversation.text: No, I bought it from a fishmonger's
Pat the perch fillet dry with a paper towel
evidence: Pat the fish fillets dry with a piece of paper towel

conversation.text: Ok. What do I do next?
Sprinkle both sides of the fish with salt and pepper
evidence: sprinkle salt and pepper over both sides of each fillet

conversation.text: How much should I use?
About 1tsp of each seasoning per fillet
evidence: about 1 tsp (4.9 mL) of each seasoning per fillet

conversation.text: Great. Now what do I do?
Flour your perch fillet
evidence: Dip the fillet in flour

conversation.text: How do I do that exactly?
Add 15ml of flour per fillet to a bowl. Then, dip the fillets one by one into the bowl, pressing the flour into each side of the fillet. How is it looking?
evidence: Pour 1 US tbsp (15 mL) of flour per fillet in a large bowl.
Place one fillet at a time in the flour, then flip it over and press the opposite side into the flour.

conversation.text: That looks great. What is the next step?
Beat one egg into a bowl, and then add the floured fillet so that both sides are covered in the egg mix.
evidence: Beat 1 egg in a bowl until the yolk and white are scrambled together.
Then dip the fish fillet in the beaten egg so that both side are covered.

conversation.text: What should it look like?
A bit like a wet chicken nugget, only bigger. Does it look good?
Yes, it does. What is the next step?
Dip the fillets into a bowl of breadcrumbs, making sure to cover each side.
evidence: Transfer the fillet to a bowl of crumbs

conversation.text: What is the best type of breadcrumb to use?
Any type you like, although cornmeal will make it sweeter
evidence: You can use whatever breadcrumbs you like
You can also use cornmeal instead of breadcrumbs for a sweeter flavor.

conversation.text: Thank you. What's next?
One important thing. Don't stack the fillets after you coat them, because the breadcrumbs may fall off. Have you breaded them successfully?
evidence: Don't stack the fillets, since this can cause the breading to come off

conversation.text: Yes, I have. How do I need to cook them?
Heat some oil in a skillet. When it is hot (when it starts to pop), add the fillets to the pan
evidence: Heat oil in a large fry pan or iron skillet.

conversation.text: What type of oil should I use?
About 15ml of any oil with a high smoke point
evidence: about 1 US tbsp (15 mL) per fillet you’re frying
You can use any oil with a high smoke point.

conversation.text: Ok, what can I use to flip the fish?
A large spatula is fine
evidence: Use a large spatula to get completely under the fillet and flip it over.

conversation.text: How long should I cook the fish for?
Around 2 minutes per side. What colour is the fillet at the moment?
evidence: The side is done when it's a light golden brown color
It should take about 2 minutes per side to fry the fish.

conversation.text: A light golden brown colour
Perfect. They are ready to eat! Take them out of the skillet and serve with the juice of half a lemon
evidence: Garnish the fillets with the juice of half a lemon.

conversation.text: Ok. Can I keep them in the fridge for a few days too?
Of course. They will last up to 3 days in the fridge
evidence: You can store leftovers for up to 3 days in a refrigerator

conversation.text: Thanks for your help!
No problem. Bon appetit!
Thank you very much!
Congratulations! You have successfully completed this cooking task.
It was really delicious!

procedure.description: Pat the fish fillets dry with a piece of paper towel. Then sprinkle salt and pepper over both sides of each fillet. Use about 1  tsp (4.9 mL) of each seasoning per fillet. If you caught the perch yourself, you'll want to fillet your perch first.
Pour 1 US tbsp (15 mL) of flour per fillet in a large bowl. Place one fillet at a time in the flour, then flip it over and press the opposite side into the flour.

procedure.summary: Dip the fillet in a bowl of beaten egg.
procedure.description: Beat 1 egg in a bowl until the yolk and white are scrambled together. Then dip the fish fillet in the beaten egg so that both side are covered.

procedure.summary: Transfer the fillet to a bowl of crumbs.
procedure.description: Once the fillet has been dipped in egg, place it in a bowl of breadcrumbs and press both sides in the crumbs so the whole fillet is covered. You can use whatever breadcrumbs you like. You can also use cornmeal instead of breadcrumbs for a sweeter flavor.

procedure.summary: Repeat the coating process for each fillet.
procedure.description: It’s easiest to dip one fillet at a time in the flour, egg, and breadcrumbs. As you finish coating each fillet, lay it flat on a plate or platter. Don't stack the fillets, since this can cause the breading to come off.

procedure.summary: Heat oil in a large fry pan or iron skillet.
procedure.description: You should use about 1 US tbsp (15 mL) per fillet you’re frying. Pour the oil in a large fry pan or iron skillet and heat it over medium high heat. You can use any oil with a high smoke point. This includes grapeseed, extra virgin olive, and sunflower oil.

Once the oil is hot (you can tell if the oil starts to pop), place the fillets in the fry pan. Check them every few minutes, especially if you’re adding fillets at different times.The side is done when it's a light golden brown color.

procedure.summary: Use a spatula to flip the perch.
procedure.description: Once 1 side of the perch is brown, it's time to flip it. Use a large spatula to get completely under the fillet and flip it over. Once the second side is golden-brown, you can remove the fillet from the pan. It should take about 2 minutes per side to fry the fish.

If you’ve fried the fish in an iron skillet, you can also use the skillet the serve the fish – just make sure you place a pot holder under the skillet before you set it on the table. If you’ve used a fry pan, use a spatula to carefully remove the fish. Garnish the fillets with the juice of half a lemon. You can store leftovers for up to 3 days in a refrigerator.
